rules.name: Establish the Current Conditions
rules.description: In a change proposal, you first want to establish the current conditions. These are the present conditions in need of change. Another common name for the current conditions is the status quo.

children.name: What are the current conditions?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by associating words/phrases from the user-defined topic cluster “Current Conditions” with words/phrases that convey elaboration impressions--impressions that furnish neutral background.

Consider a writer who is a member of their college's rowing club. The writer can think of many neutral, positive, and negative things to say about club. Neutrally, the rowing club has been in existence for decades, has at any time about twenty members, and recruits students from across campus. Positively, the rowing club has won many competitive awards against other clubs from other colleges and boasts many student athletes. Negatively, the rowing club is not a varsity sport and it faces many uphill disadvantages because it is not. The change proposed will be to make it a varsity sport.

When answering this question, the expectation is that you will associate the “Current Conditions” with neutral impressions. You will associate the topical cluster “Current Conditions” with “rowing” and “rowing club” and in the predicate you will elaborate these topics with neutral impressions of the club that helps orient readers to the issue.

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases you associate with the present condition.

children.examples:
The rowing club at our university was founded in 1985 and takes in students from many majors across campus.

The technical interview process is something almost all computer science majors go through when they graduate.

Interviewers recruit students who can exhibit a throough and mature thought process.

This generation of college students is well-known to be actively involved in community service.

Most campus eateries provide allergen sheets that list the allergens in their foods.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you make your writing more considerate. Your reader needs a neutral picture of what's going on now as a baseline for helping the reader understand why you are invested in the status quo and why you want to change it. By supporting the reader's need for this neutral picture before you complicate it, your text is considerate.

children.name: What's positive about these conditions?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by aligning “Current Conditions” in the subject slot with positively-aligned (or simply positive) impressions in the predicate slot.

Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. The rower will want to create positive information about the current conditions that makes investment in that upgrade persuasive. Positive words and phrases associated with the current rowing club might be “recruits committed individuals”, “has won many trophies in community competition”, and “respresents some of the university's best scholar-athletes”.

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases you associate with the present condition.

children.examples:
The rowing club has boasted many top student athletes over the years.

Today's students are greatly interested in learning everything they can about personal finance.

The sacrifices many students now make to earn a college degree are laudable.

Students often consider lifetime earning power and peronal happiness as different but important factors when considering a major.

Even students who pride themsevles on making it to class consistently and on-time are having more trouble doing so.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you show your reader that the status quo contains positive features not only worth preserving but worth investing in further. Your positive investment in the current conditions enhances your crediblity to steward the status quo into the future and that in turn makes your writing more compelliing. In addition, to comprehend your proposal, your reader needs a clear picture of what's right about the current conditions to understand why the status quo deserves additional investment. Your support of the reader's comprehension and informed judgment makes you a considerate writer.

children.name: What's negative about these conditions? (gaps)
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by associating the topical cluster “Current Conditions” with the impression of negatively-aligned (or simply negative) information. The resulting sentences will be “gap” sentences, sentences that pinpoint where change is needed.

Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. The rower will want to list negative information about the current conditions that makes change seem necessary. Negative words and phrases associated with the current conditions might be that, because rowing remains only a club and not a varsity sport, the college “loses top recruits to other schools while the rowers are left to rely on ”outdated rowing equipment“, and ”inadequate“ medical coverage compared to the coverage extended to the members of the varsity sports.

topics.prompt: List the negative words and phrases you associate with the present condition.

children.examples:
The rowing club on this campus is imperiled because it has not been granted status as a variety sport.

The current tests that many technology companies give to evalulate student applicant programming skills are unfair and invalid meausres of what professional programmers need to do on the job.

A street that hundreds of students cross per hour to get to their classes lacks crosswalks, stop signs, and traffic lights, and is a prsent danger to students.

Our campus currently has no eatery that satisfies the nutritional requirements of vegans.

There is a dearth of reporters on the campus newspaper primarily due to apathy.
children.cv_description: By creating easily identifiable and troubling gap sentences, you show your crediblity to motivate change and you show your considerateness to readers to prepare them to comprehend the change you propose.

rules.name: Present My Change Proposal
rules.description: After you have established the current conditions, you are ready to present your proposal for change.

children.name: What concrete change(s) do I propose?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by including as topic clusters the specific changes you propose. You don't need to worry about tracking impressions in these sentences.

Let's return to our rower who wants to make rowing a varsity sport on campus. The change proposed is the topic cluster “make rowing a varsity sport” or simply “varsity sport”. Sentences containing that topic, and variations, should recur consistently throughout the change proposal, and with each recurrence, the reader will take it for the proposed solution.

topics.prompt: List all the words and phrases associated with the change you propose.

children.examples:
Rowing needs to be turned into a varsity sport.

Companies need fairer ways to test the ability of programmers.

The university needs to place a stop sign and crosswalk at this dangerous intersection.

Dining services on campus should label all foods sold with nutritional and allergenic information.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you make it easy for your reader to pick out your proposed change and this makes your text a considerate text.

rules.name: Show How My Proposal Fills the Gaps
rules.description: In a change proposal, you need to show how your proposal addresses the gaps in the present situation.

children.name: How does my proposal fill the gaps?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by including words and phrases for your proposed change in the subject position and positively-aligned (positive) impressions in the predicate position.

Consider our rowing example where the proposed change is to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. Here the phrase “varsity sport” would be part of a topic cluster related to the proposed change and it would be related to positive phrases like

  • “Making rowing a varsity sport will help recruit the best rowers graduating from high school”
  • “As a varsity sport, rowing will put our rowing team on the map”
  • “Upgrading rowing to a varsity sport will grow our population of student athletes”

topics.prompt: List all the words and phrases associated with the change you propose.

children.examples:
Making rowing a varsity sport will double our population of student athletes.

By making company tests for hiring programmers open book and focused on practical problems, companies will make better hiriing decisions and students coming out of school will be treated more fairly.

Placing a stop sign and crosswalk on Elm and Fifth will improve the safety of students who rely on that intersection to get to classes. It will also send the message that the university makes student safety a top priority.

Creating an eatery on campus that is entirely vegan will accommodate the increasing number of students who are vegan or who want to explore a vegan lifestyle. It will also help recruit students from high school who are vegan or want to try it in their college years.

By developing a policy on campus free speech that respects free speech as a constitutional right while upholding the university's values of respect and dignity for all is important for maintaining a healthy campus climate, encouraging open inquiry, and better deflecting hate speech.
children.cv_description: By crafting sentences that meet this expectation, you show you can credibly (from a problem-solving point of view) and compellingly (from a reader point of view) link your proposed change to tangible advantages.
children.parent: Show How My Proposal Fills the Gaps

children.name: How does my proposal affirm the values of my target audience?
children.description:
How Is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by identifying your target audience as a user-defined topical cluster in subject position; in the predicate, specify (as impressions) the positive values exemplified by your proposed change that your target audience also cherishes.

topics.prompt: List the target audiences that are most important for turning your proposal into reality.

children.examples:
The university has an overriding interest to recruit the best student-athletes graduating from high school. It happens that, across all sports, rowing attracts some of the best student athletes.

The university has a significant interest in the safety of students. And this is why making campus intersections safe is such a compelling interest.

Campus leaders undertand that while students are here to acquire knowledge, their health and nutritional well-being are also very important.

Tech companies hiring programmers out of college need students who can solve practical programming problems. If they are to meet this need, they need to make sure they screen for applicants with this practical programming sense.
children.cv_description: By linking the values of your change proposal to the deepest values of your target audience, you make your text compelling.
children.parent: Show How My Proposal Fills the Gaps

rules.name: Acknowledge the Limitations In My Proposal
rules.description: In a change proposal, your proposal is bound to have some limitations and you need to acknowledge them.

children.name: What are the limitations of my proposal?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by associating your proposed change early in the sentence with the negatively-aligned (negative) impressions following later in the predicate. It's often advisable to front these sentences with beginnings like “I acknowledge|I recognize|I concede”.

topics.prompt: List all the words and phrases associated with the change you propose.

children.examples:
I acknowlege that my proposal comes with an expensive price tag.

After talking to unversity officials, I learned that we can get a vegan eatery, but only if we eliminate an existing eatery.

I recognize that my proposal to expand greek life on campus is a low priority for the administration.

A bike-sharing program for campus, which I propose, was tried a few years ago and it failed.
children.cv_description: Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing to a varsity sport. This is an appealing solution for the rowing club. But it is also an expensive solution. And the university has many sports to support! Proposal writers lose credibility when they fail to address the limitations in their proposal. They also show lapses of ethical balance by appearing to think that the strengths of their proposal should count more than the weaknesses and a lapse of ethics and considerateness by failing to be transparent about their weaknesses.
children.parent: Acknowledge the Limitations In My Proposal

rules.name: Address the Limitations in My Proposal
rules.description: In a change proposal, you will want to address the limitations in your proposal. In some cases, the limitations come from misimpressions that you will want to correct. In many cases, the limitations come because your proposal is too ambitious, too expensive, or has too many moving parts to show gains in a reasonable amount of time. In such cases, you will want to show your willingness to scale back on aspects of your proposal if your audience finds the full proposal unworkable.

children.name: How do I address these limitations?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by creating a new topical cluster around the limitations in your proposal. Include these limitations in your sentences. In the same sentence or adjoining sentences, indicate scaled-down adjustments or refinements you'd be willing to make if your entire proposal strikes your audience as too big. Continue to emphasize the positive benefits that can still result from these scale-downs.

Words and phrases associated with such accommodating language are the following:

  • “If/While my full proposal is too big for immediate implementation, we can proceed incrementally”
  • “If need be, we can define some first steps that are more affordable and less controversial”

topics.prompt: Indicate the words and phrases that reference the scale-downs, compromises, and adjustments you woiuld be willing to make if your proposal can't be accepted at its original size or scope.

children.examples:
Making rowing a varsity sport has a range of upfront and hidden costs that we may not be able to afford. If that is the case, we might think of a one-time investment to bring the equipment up to well-recognized standards of performance and safety.

If a traffic light and cross-walk are too expensive for this intersection, we should consider a stop sign or even a "yield to pedestrian" sign. That could still turn out to be very effective.

An eatery dedicated to vegan food may be logistically and financially challenging for the university. If that is the case, I have checked and it would be less challenging to make sure a few existing eateries increase their stock of vegan products. Even a modest increase could go a long way addressing the problem.

Completely changing the corporate tests for student programmers may be impossible for many computer companies. However, even if that were the case, there would be no great effort or cost in allowing the tests to be open-book to cut down on meaningless memorization.
children.cv_description: By addressing the limitations of your proposal, you show you are interested in presenting a balanced account (ethical) that is respectful of the reader's potential objections and concerns (considerate). And these impressions in turn contribute to the reader's perception of your credibility as a writer and your willingness to co-construct the proposal with the audience/potential funder to make it compelling.
children.parent: Address the Limitations in My Proposal
